comment: i removed "scentific learning" from paragraph 1 (last time both words but re-entered learning). as scientific learning is based on systematic approach to learning which is derived from intellegence

[[Image:Efez Celsus Library 3 RB.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Personification]] of wisdom (in [[Greek Language|Greek]], "''Σοφία''" or "''Sophia''") at the [[Celsus Library]] in [[Ephesos]], [[Turkey]].]]
    −
'''Wisdom''' is philosophical, insight into others' inner qualities and the nature of human relationships, and generally good sense or judgment.<ref> ''Wisdom''. Merriam-Webster Dictionary</ref> To some extent the terms wisdom and [[intelligence]] have similar and overlapping meanings.
+
'''Wisdom''' is philosophical learning, insight into others' inner qualities and the nature of human relationships, and generally good sense or judgment.<ref> ''Wisdom''. Merriam-Webster Dictionary</ref> To some extent the terms wisdom and [[intelligence]] have similar and overlapping meanings.
     
Some see wisdom as a quality that even a child, otherwise immature, may possess independently of experience or wide knowledge. The status of wisdom or prudence as a [[virtue]] is recognized in [[cultural]], [[philosophical]] and [[religious]] sources. Some define wisdom in a [[utilitarian]] sense, as foreseeing consequences and acting to maximize the long-term common [[goodness|good]].{{Fact|date=March 2007}} As such, wisdom is viewed as consisting of ideals and principles that govern all actions and decisions.
 
Some see wisdom as a quality that even a child, otherwise immature, may possess independently of experience or wide knowledge. The status of wisdom or prudence as a [[virtue]] is recognized in [[cultural]], [[philosophical]] and [[religious]] sources. Some define wisdom in a [[utilitarian]] sense, as foreseeing consequences and acting to maximize the long-term common [[goodness|good]].{{Fact|date=March 2007}} As such, wisdom is viewed as consisting of ideals and principles that govern all actions and decisions.
